comment._content: For more information about the SS Orient: www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2362703683/ and www.laird-bogstown.com/orient 1.php

comment.author: 47572660@N08
comment._content: Yes, beachcomberaustralia, it looks French to me, possibly 'Pacifique', which means 'peaceful'.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Thanks for that Wardie44B, or 'Merci'. The French steamship "Pacifique" (built 1899) was owned by the M M (Compagnie des Messageries Maritimes - see note on flag) a French state-owned operation. She was 1,938 tons and (probably) operated the Marseilles - Port Said - Mahe - Reunion - Mauritius - Adelaide - Melbourne - Sydney - Noumea route. She was scrapped in 1925. Ref.- www.theshipslist.com/ships/lines/mm.htm . The earliest reference to the SS Pacifique in the Sydney Morning Herald is an advertisement for sailing to Noumea at 1pm on Wednesday 15 November 1899 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14233925?searchTerm=SS pacifique . This might not be the sailing that was about to happen in this photo, but it is certainly c.1900. The scaffolding in front of the Customs House (they were adding extra floors) also is evident in this photo - www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/3794327782/ .

comment.author: 47572660@N08
comment._content: Yes, a number of differences, beachcomber. What does is signify that the Pacifique isn't flying any flags (well, not the one on top and not the French flag) in the other image?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Wardie44B, I have no idea, other than the Pacifique is not about to leave port.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I just came across this article in the SMH of Tuesday 31/10/1899 (I was looking for something else as usual). A very full description of the Pacifique . Read all about her! - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14229278 I bet these photos are contemporary with the article.
